children.subject: That was before the revamp of the class material.
But in Spring 2017 the curve was great, it's just the instructor's style of assigning grade. Same with Hilfinger's 61B vs Hug's 61B.
According to Berkeleytutor, the AVG GPA for both profs is similar for 61B and are very comparable to one another.
Check Fall 2017 vs Spring 2018. In Fall 2017 47% A, and in Spring 2018 17% A
Definitely this semester's CS 189 is harder to get A but the information of different instructor's style of assigning grade is also available...

They purposely withheld info in regards to the curve. Many people asked about it and they said it would be similar.

 

 

That was very simply NOT the case.

The professor may means that it is similar to Fall 2016, the semester that was also taught by him. In regards to research, check Spring 2016's CS 188, which is also a course important for research that only gave out 10% A. Also I know my friends who took Hug's 61B and didn't get in the major. Many of us postponed a semester to take CS 189 and we also missed out many opportunities since many research require students who have completed CS 189. I don't think there is anything to complain about since Fall 2016's curve is there on BerkeleyTime.
^^ The instructors are not obligated to reveal details of the curve or the grading process to you (other than the grading breakdown). It is solely at their discretion.
In Fall 2016 the curve for CS 189 was not that good, and the instructors are the same.

history.content:
My brother got an A- in 189 and was hired at Google's AI research in New York and got tons of offers in the Bay Area as well before accepting the Google offer. My friend works at Apple and didn't even take 189. Another friend got into AI/ML grad school at CMU without taking 189 lol. Relax. 67% of the class getting some sort of A is super generous and honestly I'm surprised 189 doesn't follow every other EECS class which only gives out about 33% A's and A-'s

--

There were multiple other issues in regards to this course like no HW Parties, not getting back HWs on a timely basis, among others. Like I said, this semester nearly 50% of the class apparently dropped the course. And the issue is that next semester the curve will be good again. It is fine if the curve doesn't fluctuate, but it is not OK if it does. Someone that could have gotten an A in a previous semester might actually get a B+ this semester based on my calculations on the curve stats.

That is simply not fair imo.

--

It's instructors right though. As a student who was also complaining on 189 piazza, spent days and nights doing all HWs,  I would say there is no fair or unfiar, we also have the right to have taken it next semester but we didn't. I was hoping for a nice curve but don't think anybody is to blame. PS: to the anon below, I also took hug's  Fall 61B last semester and it seems I am so unlucky to face the two toughest curved semesters LOL

--

I agree^. Think about how Hug's students feel when they see their peers in Fall 61B getting < 50% on all the exams but still getting A's and A+'s. Is it unfair? Probably. But that's academia for you.

---

There is still a big difference between 61B and 189. In 61B, they make it very clear what the curve would be. In 189 they purposely withheld that info. 61B is not a class whose grade determines whether you get that interview. This semester, Apple clearly stated they look at CS189 grades when determining if you get an interview. Very different scenarios.

--

bruh did you not even read my first response. My friend works with Apple's ML team and he didn't even take 189. That info session guy clearly didn't know what he was talking about

--

It must be a new thing. There literally was a slide in the presentation that said this, and the main speaker talked about it during the presentation. It was very clearly not a matter of "That info session guy clearly didn't know what he was talking about."

________________________________________________-
I think people are being quite naive about this.
1. The grading follows departmental guidelines.
2. Its the instructor's right to assign grades the way they want and they are NOT OBLIGATED to follow previous semesters.

You can express your disappointment all you want but I just wanted to say that you have no idea how the system works. In the Math department, the difference between two professors teaching is not 45% As vs. 67% As but rather whether you even pass the course. I would venture to say that professor Sahai gave grades that no other professor has given for any mainstream undergrad class in the department. Therefore, it doesn't make sense to expect the same from other professors teaching the course.

I understand getting that stellar A/A+ might be important for getting ML research. But apart from that, I don't think Apple or any other company even checks your transcript. Moreover, Apple doesn't hold infosessions, they have a "networking day" so not sure which infosession you're talking about which only you seem to have gone to.
Lastly, and again, the staff is NOT obligated to provide homework parties or Piazza support. Just because such extensive support is imparted to us in the lowerdiv EECS classes does not entitle us for the same in the upperdivs.

tl;dr I think there's more to life (even if ML is your life) than getting an A in 189. I think companies definitely care more about your projects/experience. And anyway, the number of ML positions in industry available to undergrads is quite severely limited so getting the perfect grade won't really differentiate you as much as solid experience.

--

https://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/eecs.html?view=quick&timeframe=month&date=2018-09-01&filter=Secondary%20Event%20Type&filtersel=

I don't know what you are on about; it clearly says Apple Tech Talk Information Session on Sept. 11... There were tons people there...

You can't say that what I am saying is not true if you didn't even go to it...

--

@OP I think you have the right to email instructors to express your frustration but asking everyone to email them is like spamming and will only make things worse, instead of solving the problem.

My brother got an A- in 189 and was hired at Google's AI research in New York and got tons of offers in the Bay Area as well before accepting the Google offer. My friend works at Apple and didn't even take 189. Another friend got into AI/ML grad school at CMU without taking 189 lol. Relax. 67% of the class getting some sort of A is super generous and honestly I'm surprised 189 doesn't follow every other EECS class which only gives out about 33% A's and A-'s

That is simply not fair imo.

My brother got an A- in 189 and was hired at Google's AI research in New York and got tons of offers in the Bay Area as well before accepting the Google offer. My friend works at Apple and didn't even take 189. Another friend got into AI/ML grad school at CMU without taking 189 lol. Relax. 67% of the class getting some sort of A is super generous and honestly I'm surprised 189 doesn't follow every other EECS class which only gives out about 33% A's and A-'s

--

There were multiple other issues in regards to this course like no HW Parties, not getting back HWs on a timely basis, among others. Like I said, this semester nearly 50% of the class apparently dropped the course. And the issue is that next semester the curve will be good again. It is fine if the curve doesn't fluctuate, but it is not OK if it does. Some one that could have gotten an A in a previous semester might actually get a B+ this semester based on my calculations on the curve stats.

That is simply not fair imo.

--

It's instructors right though. As a student who was also complaining on 189 piazza, spent days and nights doing all HWs,  I would say there is no fair or unfiar, we also have the right to have taken it next semester but we didn't. I was hoping for a nice curve but don't think anybody is to blame.

My brother got an A- in 189 and was hired at Google's AI research in New York and got tons of offers in the Bay Area as well before accepting the Google offer. My friend works at Apple and didn't even take 189. Another friend got into AI/ML grad school at CMU without taking 189 lol. Relax. 67% of the class getting some sort of A is super generous and honestly I'm surprised 189 doesn't follow every other EECS class which only gives out about 33% A's and A-'s

children.subject: What's the history of CS189? It looks like the first offering was Spring 2013, and then a revamped happened you said Fall 2017. What were the differences and emphases of Sahai's revamp -- just curious since I didn't hear about this before.

I do agree that people have the right to determine the curve as they want, but 189 this semester is tough comparable to your semester in terms that it offer no piazza support for half of the semester. In addition, anything after midterm is completely different from earlier semesters so the notes and ML book you mentioned doesn't really help

We all have our own difficulties, I also spent days and nights on HW, did all discussion worksheet (even including sp 17's). You can tell people instructor have right to decide curve, but, it's hurting if you think we have a much easier time this semester

I'm not really trying to argue that either semester was more difficult (because that's...impossible) just trying to show perspective on why the curve might be worse, because this semester's students would have had more material and time to prepare. 2 of my roommates took CS189 this semester and said that the past semester's material I shared with them were extremely helpful. I doubt that this semester's offering had entirely different material for half of the course.

Resources available to the course shouldn't really be an issue because your course grade is determined by your position in the course. It is unfair that in previous iterations being 50% percentile would get you a solid A, while this Fall you would receive a B (although we don't have complete grade distributions just yet). This isn't even accounting for the fact that 50% of the class dropped and they enforced prerequisites to have been taken for some students due to demand which I haven't seen in any of my courses before.
I don't really know where you're retrieving these statistics -I don't think distributions for 189 have been made public in the past?
If you apply for calanswers stats you can get exact statistics(exact number of each letter grade) about all course across all semesters

https://www.berkeleytime.com/grades/?course1=2347-all-fall_2017&course2=2347-all-spring_2018

The past 2 semester's distributions.

A lot of the content taught was not in the ML textbook prepared beforehand. The prior exams and homeworks did not really help us that much. Also, please do not dismiss the difficulty of our homeworks; I found them to be more rigorous and harder than the previous semester's homeworks, which I went through as practice for the midterms. We were also actually graded on homeworks by graduate students, with low averages every homework set. (no self grades.)
+1 Totally agree!
Also just to add on, Fall 2017 did not have a curve
As someone who is planning to take 189 in the future, what is the ML textbook that has been mentioned above? Are people referring to the set of lecture notes for the class, or a different work?
set of notes

When I took CS189 in Fall 2017, lecture notes literally did not exist until months after the relevant lecture because they had to be written by course staff during the semester. If you missed a lecture, you could literally fall behind for weeks struggling to make it up, as there were no scans posted online of notes, no prior notes to go off of, nothing. Homeworks were buggy to the point that you could spend 10+ hours on a question before the TAs recognized that there were problems. Discussion sections were shuttered in the middle of the semester because the GSIs teaching them were deemed too underprepared to teach. The course was vastly experimental and we suffered many pains on account of it, which Professor Sahai *generously* made up for by giving us a good curve.

The key point here is *generous*. Nobody is entitled to getting a good grade in CS189 anymore than they are entitled to getting a good grade in any other class. Students this semester had access to an entire ML textbook which prior students did not have access to, as well as hundreds of peers who had taken the class before, an infinitely more prepared course staff, and (most importantly) prior exams, discussions, hws, etc. By taking CS189 in the 3rd semester of its revamped offering, students also had an entire year to take the appropriate prerequisite coursework. These are all factors which lead to a potential for higher preparation in the class, which appropriately correlate with lower curves -CS168 did the exact same thing this semester by having harder exams as a byproduct of releasing practice exams.

At the end of the day we can argue over whether the curve was justified or "how hard" the classes were but the fact remains that the people making the curves are professionals aaand are pretty much going to do whatever they want.
Just tell companies that your CS189 grade was a noisy estimation of your true potential. ;)
I need to hug my support vector machine for emotional support
Could you post those responses here? I don't have access to the 189 piazza.

Let's not mix these two things together. Support and Curve should not be talked together and complaining about this isn't helpful at all and nothing would change. I was hoping for a nice curve but don't blame anyone since we have the right to drop the class.

To the anon above: I don't think it's appropriate to post it here since it's meaningless to trigger more anger, but still remembered instructors' post about no piazza support except hw errata at the beginning of semester, everyone was angry about thing like that.

They purposely withheld info in regards to the curve. Many people asked about it and they said it would be similar.

That was vey simply NOT the case.
they don't have to tell you, in many courses they do not

Honestly one of the most difficult aspects of 189 this semester was the course staff's attitude and "solutions" to students' concerns.  They just deactivated the 189 piazza, which I suppose is their idea of dealing with students' complaints about the curve. This isn't an isolated incident though; they made defensive, passive-aggressive posts and responses to legitimate student concerns throughout the semester.

That was posted in response to the following post:

@instructors: Why aren't there staff HW parties/Piazza support?

In recent history, this class has had regular homework parties and instructor support on Piazza -- I'm unsure why the decision was made to stop these, and I was wondering if we could get some insight from the staff on why this was the case.

 

While there are student-run homework parties (thanks to the guy who's trying to run these, by the way), there's typically only a handful of other students there (who all also need help -- and turnout is also low because... well, there's no staff).

 

And then, there are office hours, but when there's a queue of 20 people on the whiteboard...

At least, all of the OH I've been too have been like this, and I can't spend all of my time hunting around for OH that are emptier than the others.  (If there's a GSI who has consistently-empty OH, please let me know and hopefully I can make that time slot.)

 

Homework parties serve as a more efficient way for instructors to disseminate clarifications about a specific problem.  I'm sure many people have the same questions I do, and holding regular homework parties would actually allow us to all get our questions answered at once.  All of the other similar EECS classes that I've ever taken have had homework parties and they've been hugely helpful to me as a place to work with other students and get actual small-group or individual staff support.

 

Another issue exacerbating all of this is the lack of instructor support on Piazza... it's just other students answering; the blind leading the blind.  Not to trivialize the generosity of students who spend time to do this -- they're real heroes.  But for clarifications about subparts or more nuanced questions, staff input is often desired, and the lack of Piazza support in tandem with the nonexistence of homework parties is making it very difficult for us to move forward efficiently on the homeworks.

 

I still have so many questions about the intricacies of vector calculus (which was only explained in dis0 sol).  I'd like to discuss these and be able to ask follow-up questions as concepts are explained -- I don't find this conducive to Piazza, and I can't take up time during OH for non-homework because they're so crowded as it is.  Where do I do this?

 

I'll caveat all of this: I don't even really care about my grade -- I'm taking this P/NP and it's my last semester here.  But part of the reason why I decided to stay at Berkeley this extra semester was to take this class because I care about the material, and I'm not able to do that very effectively as it stands.  Homeworks are such a critical part of the learning process, and providing such minimal assistance and clarification has been detrimental to my ability to learn. 

 

I shared these concerns on the feedback form (and I know others who did as well), but maybe I can get some advice on how to proceed from here.  I guess I'm a bit lost on how I'm supposed to effectively learn course content besides going to lecture/discussion and fighting for some instructor time at crowded OH.

Inst. Ans:

We really do want to see all of you succeed and make the most of this class. We have put together this guide to help you better navigate the existing course structure @198 (link above). We hope most of your concerns are addressed in the document.
Just one ex. of how they treated their students.

Here is another example, as well as some thoughts I have about being a student in the course this semester:

The staff also posted review questions for the final (which was very kind of them considering most of the post-midterm material had not been covered in previous semesters); however, when the solutions were finally posted, many students were very confused by the solutions. It turned out that there had been many errors in the solutions and the instructors response (more than a day later and ~3 days before the final exam) was "A lot of the review solutions have not been double or triple checked, keep that in mind while studying." To me, this translated as the staff telling us, "Oh yeah, that one resource we gave you -- all of the solutions might be wrong. Good luck studying!" As a student who had spent many many hours trying to figure out what I was doing wrong and why I couldn't make sense of the solutions, I found this extremely frustrating and enraging. In my opinion, it would have been better to not give any solutions at all than to publish incorrect ones -- how were we to know if we were doing the problem wrong or if the solution was just wrong?? It's not like we could just plug these questions into wolfram alpha or anywhere else on the internet to get a (correct) solution to check our answers with.

While I did learn a lot from this course, and I am truly grateful for the time that certain GSIs put in to help me and others understand the material, I feel that this course was run horribly compared any other EE/CS class I have taken at this school. I know there is nothing we can do to make the course staff change their mind about the curve, and TBH it doesn't really matter to me because:

1) I'm okay with the grade I'm going to get

2) this class made me realize I am obviously not cut out for ML (so no grad school for me)

3) for me this isn't even about the grade at all, it is more about making sure that UCB is helping their students get the most out of the courses they choose to challenge themselves with

However, I do understand why students are upset, I think their complaints are 100% valid, and I feel for those whose grad school applications and interview prospects have been harmed by this. I'm also having a hard time understanding how making our piazza inactive was in any way an adequate solution to dealing with upset students who just want a simple explanation for why the curve was different than previous semesters. Also, 2 of our 10 homework assignments still haven't been graded! I would think they should keep our piazza active until all of the HWs have been graded in case anyone has questions about their grades or about the rubric... We all know that most of the professors at Berkeley are here for their research and teaching is just a side thing they have to do, but with all due respect, I hope that the EECS department takes the measures to make sure that the future course staffs (especially for courses as difficult as CS189) take their duties as instructors more seriously.
@OP we do not allow anon users on this piazza. Please add your full name or you will be removed.
@OP You're still not using the name on your records. Please correct or we will remove you.

In response to people asking for more resources (lowest of past semesters) and help they wrote this:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jQvxmVl12p_4g0ru0nTmUJG2HRTbgXbJZPi1MzVBe4Y/edit

As long as the curve follows the EECS department guidelines for upper division classes, there really isn't anything we can do. The course was extremely disorganized and there was a severe lack of support, and those complaints are valid. But to be fair, you could've dropped the course if you felt that it was so hindering you so badly.
Compared to 67%?
We cannot always expect curve to be same as its historical peak. We are on the same curve, I share disappointment with you but being angry is not the best way
How is 45% As a horrible curve? Sounds pretty generous to me.

I completely agree with you. @OP if companies will discriminate against you just because you didn't do well on some exam then imo they are not worth working with. If they don't look at your profile as a whole, then they you probably don't want to work for companies like that. Some food for thought: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/08/opinion/college-gpa-career-success.html

I understand the stress of not getting high grades as it seemingly make sure us ineligible for target grad schools(and possibly specific professors and research opportunities), and interviews from target companies. Then we compare with others who were luckier than you.

I can’t give you a comforting response if you don’t get into your dream school and professor, all I can say is there’s probably tons of schools and professors you can learn from. I think school prestige is overrated. I came to this school because it was my dream school, I’d choose it over Harvard and Stanford. Call me stupid, but I don’t care, I live my life the way I want and couldn’t care less if people think I’m cooler or if a VC thinks im smarter for going to Harvard over here. But nevertheless, this isn’t popular opinion so 100% respect your stress.

For Apple, there’s thousands of a ways to get an interview with them, 1 is getting an A in 189 apparently. Finding another way. Referrals, network, go work ther after graduation? Tons of ways. If they don’t dont hire you ever because you got a B+ in 189 is funny lol.
FYI, I have received multiple interviews from Apple (from different teams) and nobody ever saw my transcript? Like on the application there wasn't even a place to put the transcript?
Exactly, with so many people, grades are not what differentiate you; it is more like a cut-off tbh

Also, professors want to pick the best and brightest for AI/ML research (since the positions are highly contested), AKA the people who would be in the top 10% of the 189 class, AKA people would have gotten an A/A+ anyways.

This is a bit late, but can you let me know which semester that has up to 67% of students getting A- and above? I checked on Berkeleytime and it seems like that every semester only around 50% of students get A- and above.

history.content:
So CS189 this semester decided to make the curve much worse than it has been historically for previous semesters.

Usually around 55% of the class gets an A+/A at the end of class, with around 67% of the class getting some type of A, and instructor said that undergrads and grads are graded together while a noticeable difference exists on final grade distribution.

This semester, only 45% of the class is getting an A of some type, within which might be 25% A for grad+undergrad. This is after a historic number of students dropping the class (about 50%) and many student without the necessary prereqs being booted out of the class. (Basically, the student population left at the end of the semester is much more capable than what is average for such a class.)

I am really disappointed, and frustrated. Just this semester, Apple literally said during their infosession that they specifically look at grades in CS189 when determining whether or not to accept students for interviews. In addition, you need an A/A+ in 189 in order to participate in AI/ML research.

When specifically asked what the curve would be, we were promised a curve similar to previous semesters. This is very clearly NOT the case. Normally I would be frustrated and just leave it to myself, but 189 is too important a class for me to let this go.

What options do we as students have in order to argue for a better curve? If I am going to be compared in the real world against students that took 189 in different semesters, the curves should at the very least be comparable.

NOTE:

The prof emails are here:

Moritz Hardt <hardt@berkeley.edu>,
Benjamin Recht <brecht@berkeley.edu>,
Stella Yu <stellayu@berkeley.edu>

PLEASE email them if you have issues with the curve. Deactivating the class before grades come out or before a quarter of HW grades are posted cannot be a "solution" to this issue.
history.subject: CS 189 Curve Horrible Compared to Historical - What options do we have?
